title: Accessibility statement for the Court and Tribunal Hearing Information Service

section1.text1: The Court and Tribunal Hearing Information Service provides a publishing platform to enable information provided by HMCTS to be shared, displayed and updated as appropriate. It will enable lists, outcomes, judgments and information to be displayed to court users, consistent with jurisdictional procedures and business rules. The service supports HMCTS’ commitment to open justice and the provision of transparent and consistent court/tribunal information across all jurisdictions.
section1.text2: This accessibility statement applies to content published on
section1.text3: It is based on an accessibility audit for carried out by the Digital Accessibility Centre (DAC) user / technical team on 1 March 2022.
section1.text4: This website is run by HM Courts and Tribunals. We want as many people as possible to be able to use this website, so we have designed it to be accessible. For example, that means you should be able to:

section2.heading: How accessible is this website?
text: The summary findings from the accessibility audit reported that users who are cognitively impaired, or use voice activated or keyboard only access, could navigate the site completely independently, with no issues. Users with dyslexia, who were colour blind or had low vision could navigate the site completely independently, but with minor issues.
Two high-level accessibility issues have been reported, mostly affecting those using screen readers.
The Single Justice Procedure (SJP) Public list, which shows SJP cases and outcomes, is presented in a PDF document that is particularly difficult for screen reader users to navigate.
The service sign-in and screens associated with a user needing to reset their password do not follow GDS design principles and are not accessible.

section5.heading: Enforcement procedure
section5.text1: The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) is responsible for enforcing the Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018 (the ‘accessibility regulations’). If you’re not happy with how we respond to your complaint,

links.text: contact the Equality Advisory and Support Service (EASS) (opens in a new window).

section6.heading: Contacting us by phone or visiting us in person
text: We provide a text relay service for people who are D/deaf, hearing impaired or have a speech impediment.
Our courts and tribunals have audio induction loops, or if you contact us before your visit we can arrange a British Sign Language (BSL) interpreter.

section7.heading: Technical information about this website’s accessibility
section7.text1: HM Courts and Tribunal Service is committed to making its websites accessible, in accordance with the Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018.

section8.heading: Compliance status
section8.text1: This website is partially compliant with the
section8.text2: AA standard, due to ‘the non-compliances’ listed below.
text: The Single Justice Procedure (SJP) Public list

Some hearing lists are presented within the service are presented and viewable in a PDF document. These are presented in a PDF document that is particularly difficult for screen reader users to navigate. The content was untagged, untitled and the tables were not marked up semantically to enable screen reader users to navigate and identify the information correctly.

Under the HMCTS Reform Programme, the aim is that source data for these lists will be provided by source systems to the Court and tribunal hearings service, for this service to present in an accessible style sheet. This may not always be possible due to service outages. The frequency of lists displayed in a PDF should be in frequent. Feedback has been given to the source systems that when they produce PDF’s they should do so in an accessible way.

Until such time as a PDF document from a source system is accessible, it will not be possible for this service to be fully compliant. Progress will be reviewed on an ongoing basis, with a full review in December 2022.

The service sign-in for a user with a court and tribunal hearings account and screens associated with a user needing to reset their password do not follow GDS design principles and are not accessible.
The interface is based on the Microsoft Azure cloud platform and HMCTS has reported to Microsoft that the patterns used are not WCAG 2.1AA compliant.
There is a dependency on Microsoft to resolve the non-compliance. The service team will engage with Microsoft and monitor progress, with a review set for December 2022.

section9.heading: What we’re doing to improve accessibility
text: HMCTS has already addressed a number of issues raised by the accessibility report which fall within its control.

Where the service fails to meet the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines version 2.1 AA standard, HMCTS will proactively engage with the department’s Reform Programme to ensure that integration with Common Platform will be monitored and progressed. The service team will continue to engage with Microsoft to progress its report relating to Microsoft Azure.
This statement will be reviewed and updated in December 2022.

section10.text5: This accessibility statement applies to content published on

section10.text7: The following provides an excerpt showing the methodology adopted.
section10.text8: “The service is tested by a team of experienced auditors and analysts, many of who are disabled individuals and users of adaptive technology. The combination of subjective pan-disability user feedback and comprehensive technical auditing allows us to measure how the service performs technically and practically, thereby offering an essential added dimension to our test results that other methods of testing cannot provide.”
section10.text9: “Manual accessibility checking was conducted by a team of disabled individuals, using a range of adaptive technologies (hardware and software designed to facilitate the use of computers by people with disabilities).”

This combined with an extensive knowledge of WCAG, its application and wider global practice provides the DAC website with further credibility and quality.”
